## 2023 Assessment: Major Changes and Improvements {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.65em; line-height: 1.4;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}

### Catch-conditioned model:

- Reduced from 11,421 to 3,067 parameters
- More stable convergence

### sdmTMB CPUE standardization:

- Spatial-temporal modeling framework
- Replaced VAST approach

### Lorenzen natural mortality:

- Size/age-dependent M scaling
- More realistic mortality patterns

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

### Growth estimation:

- Von Bertalanffy parameters internally estimated
- Use of conditional age-at-length data
  
### Uncertainty grid expanded:

- Both structural & parameter uncertainties incorporated

### Improved model convergence:

- Diagnostic model achieved positive definite Hessian
- 48 of 54 grid models converged

:::
:::

:::


## 2023 Assessment: Remaining Challenges {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}

### Key Challenges
- Model instability (sensitivity to starting values)
- Limited age data (1,004 otoliths)
- Spatial structure complexity (9 regions)
- Size composition conflicts with tagging
- Tag mixing period uncertain

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}


### SC19 Evaluation[@sc19outcomes]:

- "More rigorous... but **model instability remains**"
- **Result**: **14 research recommendations**

## Issue #1: Age Data Quality {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="52%"}
### Problem

- **Only 1,004 otoliths**

- Limited spatial and temporal coverage (mostly 2009-2018)

### Impact

- Maybe insufficient for internal growth estimation

### SC19-#1, #7, #10

- Continue age data collection

- evaluate growth/mortality variability

- explore regional traits

### Possible improvements

- Add more otoliths collected by Japanese colleagues

- Use tagging data to estimate growth?


:::

## Issue #2: Spatial Structure {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="52%"}
### Problem
- This complexity may have caused:
  - Convergence issues (parameter identifiability issues)

### Evidence Supporting 6-Region [@hamer2023spatial]:

- Low tropical $\leftrightarrow$ temperate movement

- High mixing within tropical/temperate zones

### SC19-#4

- Simulation study: 6-region vs 9-region performance

- "areas-as-fleets" approach

### Possible Approach

- Include 6R as a grid (or as one-off sensitivity)
  -  Time constraints may hinder rigorous simulation testing given other priorities and complexity of the models

:::

![9 region structure in 2023 [@day2023bet]](figures/prepaw/9region.png){width=100%}

![Proposed 6 region structure [@hamer2023spatial]](figures/prepaw/spatial-fig-004.png){width=100%}

## Issue #4: Size Composition Weighting {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="52%"}
### Problem

- **No iterative reweighting in 2023**:
  - Fixed weights (no iterative weighting due to time constraints)
  - Data conflicts unresolved:
    - **Weight comp vs length/tagging** pull opposite directions 

### SC19-#11, #12

- Review representativeness; investigate inversion

### Possible Approaches
- Explore Francis reweighting method and Dirichlet-multinomial approaches
- Convert weight comp to length comp externally

## Issue #5: Unfished Biomass Trends {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="52%"}
### Problem

- Unfished SSB **increases over time** in tropical regions (3,4,7,8)

### Potential Causes

- Regional recruitment allocation patterns
- Movement misspecification
- Initial population distribution assumptions

### SC19-#5

Investigate model specifications causing this trend

### Possible Approaches
- Change in spatial structure (6R vs 9R)
- Adding Effort creep in CPUE indices
- Penalize extreme recruitment deviations

:::

::: {.column width="48%"}
![Fished vs Unfished SSB by region [@day2023bet]](figures/prepaw/bet2023-fig-053.png){width=100%}
:::
:::

## Issue #6: Model Convergence {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.62em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="48%"}
### Problems

- **Sensitivity to initial conditions**:
  - Models achieve suboptimal local minima

- **Jittering to find better convergence**:
  - Jittering normally used for diagnostics (robustness check) 
  - **Every grid model improved** through jittering (model not at global minimum)
  
### SC19-#9, #13: 

- Identify correlated/sensitive parameters; strategies to decrease starting value sensitivity

### Possible Approaches

- Model simplification
- Self-consistency checks to investigate which parameters are unidentifiable

:::

::: {.column width="52%"}
### Jittering in 2023 Assessment [@day2023bet]

::: {style="background-color: #fff5f5; padding: 0.7em; border-left: 4px solid #d32f2f; margin-bottom: 0.8em;"}
> "**Model convergence is a significant issue** for these complex models... **jittering is an important process** to refine and improve the best solution."
:::

::: {style="background-color: #fff5f5; padding: 0.7em; border-left: 4px solid #d32f2f; margin-bottom: 0.8em;"}
> "Jittered solutions achieved **improved objective function values** and **notable changes to derived management quantities**. This was cause for **considerable concern**."
:::

::: {style="background-color: #fff5f5; padding: 0.7em; border-left: 4px solid #d32f2f;"}
> "**Every grid model** improved through jittering — **none was at a global minimum**, even those 46 with positive definite Hessians."
:::
:::
:::

:::

# Backup Slides {data-background-color="#A5AAAF"}

## Other Potential Improvements (Personal Thoughts) {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}

### Ensemble Weighting

- **Current approach**: Equal weighting across grid models
- **Alternative weighting schemes**:
  - AIC-based weights
  - Prior density on grid axes
  - Other performance-based metrics

### Grid Expansion

- **Current limitation**: Full factorial design
  - Some combinations may be biologically unrealistic
  - Example: High M with low growth is implausible

- **Proposed approach**: Pre-screening of grid axes
  - Post-model-pre-data simulations to identify unrealistic combinations
  - Parameter bounds to limit feasible parameter space
  - Correlation structure from pre-screening used for ensemble weighting

:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

### Parametric Bootstrapping

- **Purpose**: Investigate parameter identifiability and uncertainty
- **Application**: Complement or replace jittering for robustness checks
- **Advantages**:
  - More reliable uncertainty distributions than multivariate normal approximation
  - Identify unidentifiable parameters through parameter recovery tests
  - Model validation through self-consistency checks
- **Constraints**: 
  - Computationally intensive (limit to diagnostic/key grid models)
  - Requires careful design to balance coverage and computational cost

:::
:::

:::


## 2023 Catch Trends {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="45%"}
**WCPO BET Annual Catches (1952-2021)**

- **Recent**: ~140,000 mt/year (2010s-2021)
- **Peak**: ~180,000 mt in early 2000s

**By Gear Type**:

- **Longline**: 60-70% of total catch
  - Dominant until late 1970s, then PS started increasing
  
- **Purse Seine**: 20-30%
  - Increased since early 1980s
  
- **Philippines/Indonesia Misc**: 10-15%
  - Handline, gillnet, other gears

**Trend**: Relatively stable since 2000
:::

![Annual catches by gear type [@day2023bet]](figures/prepaw/bet2023-fig-003.png){width=100%}

## Catch by Region {data-background-image="static/spc-slide-sidebar.png" data-background-size="5% 100%" data-background-position="left"}

::: {style="margin-left: 1.5%; margin-right: 1.5%; font-size: 0.6em; line-height: 1.3;"}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="45%"}
### Regional Distribution

**Tropical regions dominate**:

- **Regions 3, 4, 7, 8**: 80-90% of total
  - Equatorial zone (10°S - 10°N)
  
- **Region 7** (Indonesia/Philippines/Vietnam)
  - Largest contributor
  - 30-40% of WCPO catch
  
- **Temperate regions** (1, 2, 5, 6)
  - Seasonal fisheries
  - Relatively stable over time

### Key Concern

- **Region 7**: Poor operational data
  - Catches aggregated evenly across quarters/cells
  - Major source of uncertainty
:::

::: {.column width="55%"}
![Annual catches by region [@day2023bet]](figures/prepaw/bet2023-fig-004.png){width=100%}
:::
:::
